repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Improving children's
            health in Madagascar

abstracts.cdata!: In Madagascar, children across the country have been afflicted by a remarkably high rate of infection by various intestinal worms, which can cause anemia. A community-based response, supported by the World Bank, has brought action on several fronts, ranging from nutritional supplements to grants for school water tanks. In almost four years, SEECALINE a community nutrition program in Madagascar has treated 1.2 million students, preschoolers and non-enrolled school-aged children for intestinal parasites. The program has provided iron supplements to 800,000 students, funded 71 micro-projects, and trained 20,000 teachers. The program continues to tackle iodine deficiency - another prevalent, but easily remedied problem which causes mental retardation and poor growth in all children, and can cause younger children to become deaf. Iodine deficiency affects all children's capacity to learn.

repnme.cdata!: Madagascar - Food Security and Nutrition Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project is essentially a Government
            and Malagasy project, successfully implemented by Malagasy
            without any external long-term assistance. In Madagascar, it
            was the first project of this scope and size working with
            communities and nongovernmental organizations. One important
            outcome is that it has clearly demonstrated the benefits of
            such an approach on a scale which goes beyond previous
            attempts by pilot type operations. Given the project
            objectives as interpreted above, the outcome of the various
            components can be rated as satisfactory. Other key lessons
            learned include: The project's effectiveness was
            reinforced by the "contracting approach." Strong
            national leadership and continuity is very important for the
            success of any community nutrition project. The community
            should know from the time of entry that the program will not
            go on forever: a satisfactory community exit strategy should
            be defined and should gain acceptance. A successful program
            design includes program flexibility and training.
            Implementation plans and manuals of procedure facilitate a
            speedy and smooth implementation. Promoting behavioral
            changes through well-designed and conducted information
            campaigns (IEC) are important to sustain project objectives.
            An IEC strategy and program designed by nationals having an
            intimate understanding of local behavior and customs can
            have a high impact at low cost. The delegated contract
            management approach works well and at a reasonable cost in
            rural and urban areas.

repnme.cdata!: Madagascar - Food Security and Nutrition Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project, which is primarily active
            in two of Madagascar's six provinces, has three
            components:  (a) income generating activities to be carried
            out through:  (i) the Fonds d'Intervention pour le
            Developpement (FID) financing labor intensive works and
            other income generation activities, and (ii) a food for work
            program targeted to the urban poor in Greater Antananarivo;
            (b) nutrition interventions including:  (i) a community
            nutrition program in the provinces of Toliary and
            Antananarivo working through mothers' groups organized
            by a community nutrition agent supported by nongovernmental
            organizations to provide nutrition education, arrange
            supplemental feeding and refer severe cases of malnutrition
            to nutrition rehabilitation centers operating under medical
            supervision, and (ii) a national iodine deficiency disorders
            control program; and (c) institutional strengthening to
            support the development and execution of an information,
            education and communication program and support the
            development of a national food security strategy for the
            long term.
